   normally midline structures. Persistent prominent sulci at the left

   clinical concern related with new ischemic area, correlation with MRI
   is recommended if clinically warranted.
   - repeat Echo: Overall left ventricular systolic function is severely
   depressed (LVEF= 20-25%).  There is a very small pericardial effusion,
   no signs of tamponade.  Compared with the prior study (images reviewed)
   of [**2184-3-15**], ejection fraction is now severely depressed. The right
   ventricle, although not well seen, is dilated and hypokinetic. There is
   a small amount of pericardial fluid seen adjacent to the right atrium,
   without evidence of tamponade physiology.
   - MRI of C-spine and head: 1. Limited study due to motion. 2. No
   definite brainstem or cord signal abnormality. 3. Mild to moderate
   spinal canal stenosis at C3-4, with probable at least moderate neural
   foraminal narrowing at this level as well, though evaluation of the
   neural foramina is markedly limited due to motion.
   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval
   development of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive,
   asystolic, and pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   #Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: The first documented rhythm
   was PEA.  patient was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing CPR and
   NaHCO3 and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome
   during the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause.  Lactate during the code was 8.1.  he is currently being
   supported on levophed and fluids.  CE was elevated as expected, but not
   down trending.  He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of
   head.  New RIJ was started but femoral TL was not pulled (1 positive
   blood culture from the femoral site
 GPC in clusters).
   -vancomycin, zosyn
   -f/u bld, urine cx
   -head imaging pending clinical improvement.
   -c-spine MRI pending clinical improvement
   -need to get LP when warmed
   -trend lactate (presistently elevated to 5.1
 likely [**1-20**] to peripheral
   vasoconstriction).
   .
   #Respiratory status: oxygenating well on current settings,
   hyperventilating as well.
   - on vent continue current settings
   .
   #Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.29/30/79.  likely due to cardiac
   disfunction, poor forward flow.
   - cont. cooling protocol
   - maintain pressors
   - consider addition of ionotropic support (dopa?)
   .
   #Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- LP
   .
   #embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right femoral line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: Full
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 HYPOTHERMIA
 FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), admitted to the ICU with fevers and hypotension. He developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes, became unresponsive, and was in asystolic cardiac arrest. After resuscitation, he was found to have a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) rhythm. He is currently being supported on vasopressors and fluids.

The patient's condition is characterized by:

* Fever (101.1째F)
* Hypothermia (cooled to 32째C)
* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Respiratory acidosis (pH 7.29)
* Metabolic acidosis (lactate 5.1 mmol/L)
* Cardiac dysfunction (severely depressed left ventricular systolic function)
* Embolic stroke (newly diagnosed)
* Hyperlipidemia (stable)
* Chronic kidney disease, stage III (stable)
* Hypothyroidism (not requiring thyroid replacement at this time)
* Adrenal nodules (not requiring steroids at this time)

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis or septic shock due to the presence of a positive blood culture
* Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to cardiac dysfunction
* Respiratory failure or respiratory arrest due to respiratory acidosis
* Neurological deficits or worsening of existing stroke symptoms
* Infections or sepsis due to the presence of a central line or other invasive devices
* Bleeding or hemorrhagic complications due to the presence of a positive blood culture or other underlying conditions
* Metabolic acidosis or lactic acidosis due to inadequate tissue perfusion or other underlying conditions
* Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia due to inadequate insulin therapy or other underlying conditions
* Electrolyte imbalances or disturbances due to inadequate electrolyte management or other underlying conditions

Plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, including temperature, heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation.
* Continue to provide supportive care, including vasopressors and fluids, to maintain adequate blood pressure and perfusion.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and provide treatment as necessary to prevent cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide treatment as necessary to prevent respiratory failure or respiratory arrest.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and provide treatment as necessary to prevent worsening of existing stroke symptoms or development of new neurological deficits.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and provide treatment as necessary to prevent electrolyte imbalances or disturbances.
* Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and provide treatment as necessary to prevent hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
* Continue to monitor the patient's lactate levels and provide treatment as necessary to prevent metabolic acidosis or lactic acidosis.
* Continue to monitor the patient's blood cultures and provide treatment as necessary to prevent sepsis or septic shock.
* Consider adding ionotropic support (e.g., dobutamine) to improve cardiac function.
* Consider adding steroids to improve immune function and prevent further complications.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and provide treatment as necessary to prevent worsening of chronic kidney disease.
* Continue to monitor the patient's thyroid function and provide treatment as necessary to prevent hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism.
* Continue to monitor the patient's adrenal function and provide treatment as necessary to prevent adrenal insufficiency or hyperadrenalism.
* Consider performing a CT scan or MRI of the brain to further evaluate the patient's stroke symptoms.
* Consider performing a cardiac catheterization to further evaluate the patient's cardiac function and potential for revascularization.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 74-year-old male admitted with fevers and hypotension, later diagnosed with embolic hemorrhagic strokes. He was found unresponsive, asystolic, and pulseless, and underwent resuscitation. The patient is currently being supported on levophed and fluids and is undergoing extensive workup for fever of unknown origin (FUO).

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.1째F (38.4째C)
* Heart rate: 58 bpm
* Blood pressure: 104/50 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 17 breaths/min
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Central venous pressure: 3 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 15.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 10.6 g/dL
* Platelet count: 188 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.2 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.06 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 5.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.7 g/dL
* LDH: 684 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 6.9 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CT of the head: Scattered areas with low attenuation in the subcortical white matter, consistent with thromboembolic ischemic changes.
* MRI of the C-spine and head: Limited study due to motion, but no definite brainstem or cord signal abnormality.

The patient's medical history includes:

* Coronary artery disease (CAD)
* Hyperlipidemia
* Chronic kidney disease, stage III
* Hypothyroidism

The patient's medications include:

* Vancomycin
* Zosyn
* Levophed
* Fentanyl
* Midazolam
* Phenylephrine
* Vasopressin
* Norepinephrine
* Famotidine
* Heparin sodium

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's fever of unknown origin and positive blood culture, there is a risk of developing sepsis.
2. Embolic stroke: The patient has already experienced embolic hemorrhagic strokes, and there is a risk of further embolic events.
3. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac function is severely depressed, and there is a risk of further cardiac deterioration.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and there is a risk of developing respiratory failure.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's lactate levels are elevated, and there is a risk of developing metabolic acidosis.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's thyroid function is abnormal, and there is a risk of developing hypothyroidism.
7. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal function is abnormal, and there is a risk of developing adrenal insufficiency.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies closely.
2. Continue to provide supportive care, including levophed and fluids, and consider weaning the patient off pressors as tolerated.
3. Consider repeating the patient's imaging studies, including CT and MRI, to assess for any changes in the patient's condition.
4. Consider performing a lumbar puncture to rule out meningitis or encephalitis.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider performing a stress test or echocardiogram to assess for any changes in the patient's cardiac function.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider intubating the patient if necessary.
7. Consider performing a thyroid function test to assess for any changes in the patient's thyroid function.
8. Consider performing an adrenal function test to assess for any changes in the patient's adrenal function.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old man admitted with fevers and hypotension, who developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and pulseless, and underwent resuscitation. The patient has a complex medical history, including CAD, hyperlipidemia, chronic kidney disease, stage III, and hypothyroidism.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   #Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: The first documented rhythm
   was PEA.  patient was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing CPR and
   NaHCO3 and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome
   during the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause.  Lactate during the code was 8.1.  he is currently being
   supported on levophed and fluids.  CE was elevated as expected, but not
   down trending.  He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of
   head.  Had Femoral line with 1 postive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was started
   on [**3-25**]. Was cooled and then rewarmed.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated starting with neo
   - repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
   -f/u bld, urine cx
   -head imaging pending weaning of one pressor
   -c-spine MRI
   -consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate (presistently elevated to 5 and falling today to 2.2
   ..
   #Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   #Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.29/30/79.  likely due to cardiac
   disfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to pressors
   and cooling
   - cont. cooling protocol
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated after re-warming starting with
   neo
   .
   #Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   - d/c acyclovir
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   #embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   -start insulin
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right femoral line
   # Communication: family

   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man admitted to the ICU with fevers, hypotension, and cardiac arrest. He had a prolonged cardiac arrest and was resuscitated. The patient has been undergoing an extensive workup for fever of unknown origin (FUO) and has developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes. He is currently being supported on levophed and fluids and is being cooled and rewarmed. The patient has a history of CAD, and his cardiac function is compromised.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he is at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated and is at risk for respiratory failure due to his compromised cardiac function and potential respiratory acidosis.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has persistent metabolic acidosis with a lactate level of 5.1, which may be due to cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, and increased afterload.
4. Hypoalbuminemia: The patient has hypoalbuminemia, which may contribute to intravascular volume and pressure problems.
5. Embolic stroke: The patient has developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes, which may lead to further neurological complications.
6. Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules: The patient has hypothyroidism and adrenal nodules, which may require further endocrine evaluation and treatment.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, which may require insulin therapy to control.
8. FEN (Fever of Unknown Origin): The patient has FUO, which may require further evaluation and treatment to identify the underlying cause.
9. Prophylaxis: The patient is at risk for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP, which may require prophylactic measures.
10. Access: The patient has multiple lines and tubes, which may be at risk for complications, such as infection or dislodgement.

Overall, the patient is at risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated starting with neo
   - repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   -start insulin
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man admitted to the ICU with fevers, hypotension, and unresponsiveness. He was found pulseless and underwent resuscitation. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), and his current condition is complicated by embolic hemorrhagic strokes, respiratory alkalosis, and metabolic acidosis. He is currently receiving pressor support and is being weaned off neosynephrine. The patient's fever curve has trended down, and he is being monitored for further fevers. His respiratory status is improving, and he is being weaned off the ventilator.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac function is compromised due to the embolic hemorrhagic strokes, which may lead to further cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
2. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to complications such as seizures, coma, or even death.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he may still be at risk for respiratory failure if his lung function deteriorates further.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate the presence of an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) may indicate the presence of a coagulopathy, which could lead to bleeding complications.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may not be properly managed, leading to complications such as hypothyroidism-related symptoms, decreased cognitive function, or even cardiac complications.
7. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal function may not be properly managed, leading to complications such as adrenal crisis, hypotension, or even death.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding may worsen if not properly managed, leading to complications such as hypovolemic shock, bleeding into the peritoneum, or even death.
9. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen if not properly managed, leading to complications such as uremia, electrolyte imbalances, or even death.
10. Infection: The patient's infection may spread to other parts of his body, leading to complications such as sepsis, organ dysfunction, or even death.

These potential medical complications highlight the need for close monitoring and management of the patient's condition in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old man admitted to the ICU with a history of CAD, fevers, and hypotension. He had a cardiac arrest with pulseless electrical activity (PEA) and was resuscitated. The patient has been undergoing extensive workup for FUO (fever of unknown origin) with interval development of embolic hemorrhagic strokes.

Current vital signs:

* HR: 75 bpm
* BP: 94/50 mmHg
* RR: 21 insp/min
* SpO2: 98%
* Heart rhythm: SR (Sinus Rhythm)

The patient is receiving various medications, including vasopressors (levophed and phenylephrine), insulin, and anticoagulants (heparin). He is also receiving cooling protocol therapy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he is still on a ventilator and may require continued mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac arrest and PEA rhythm suggest potential cardiac dysfunction, which may lead to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's lactate levels are elevated, which may indicate poor perfusion or cardiac dysfunction.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fevers and elevated white blood cell count suggest potential sepsis, which may lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
5. Thromboembolic events: The patient's history of CAD and the presence of a femoral line with positive blood cultures suggest a risk of thromboembolic events.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's embolic hemorrhagic strokes and potential sepsis may lead to further neurological complications such as seizures, cerebral edema, or stroke.
7. Infections: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and use of invasive lines and devices increase his risk of developing infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or central line-associated bloodstream infections.
8. Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules: The patient's history of hypothyroidism and adrenal nodules may require further monitoring and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to assess for any changes in his condition.
2. Adjust his medications and treatment plan as necessary to manage his cardiac dysfunction, metabolic acidosis, and sepsis.
3. Consider performing a head CT or MRI to rule out further neurological complications.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
5. Consider performing a gallium scan or other imaging studies to evaluate for potential sources of infection or inflammation.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his electrolyte replacement therapy as necessary.
7. Consider performing a lumbar puncture (LP) to evaluate for potential central nervous system infections.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management and medication regimen as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history, currently in the ICU. They have undergone multiple interventions, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 75 beats per minute, blood pressure of 94/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient has a history of liver disease and is currently receiving vasopressors and insulin. They have also undergone multiple lab tests, including blood cultures, which have revealed elevated liver enzymes and lipase levels.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 222 mmHg. The patient is receiving 50% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) and has a respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 48.

The patient's neurological status is impaired, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8/15. They are unable to respond to verbal commands, move, or have normal tone.

The patient's laboratory results are concerning, with elevated liver enzymes, lipase levels, and lactate levels. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's elevated liver enzymes and lipase levels, there is a risk of developing sepsis.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine levels and low urine output suggest a risk of developing AKI.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate and PaO2 levels are concerning, and there is a risk of developing respiratory failure.
4. Neurological deterioration: The patient's impaired neurological status and elevated lactate levels suggest a risk of neurological deterioration.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension and elevated lactate levels suggest a risk of cardiovascular instability.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history and multiple comorbidities. They require close monitoring and management to prevent potential medical complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated starting with neo
   - repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   -start insulin
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old man admitted to the ICU with a history of CAD, admitted with fevers and hypotension, and later developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes. He was found unresponsive, asystolic, and pulseless, and underwent resuscitation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: HR 75 bpm, BP 94/50 mmHg, RR 21 inspirations per minute, SpO2 98%
* Neurological status: Unresponsive, no movement or tone assessment
* Hemodynamic status: Pressor-dependent, able to be weaned off neosynephrine overnight
* Respiratory status: Oxygenating well, improving RSBI, on ventilator with CPAP/PSV mode
* Metabolic status: Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation, likely due to cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, and increased afterload due to pressors and cooling
* Fever curve: Trending down, with a maximum temperature of 100.1째F
* Laboratory results: WBC 28.8 K/uL, Hct 31.1%, Plt 147 K/uL, Cr 1.8 mg/dL, Glucose 297 mg/dL
* Radiology results: Negative for acute bleed on head CT
* Plan:
	+ Continue to monitor fever curve, CRP, and lactate
	+ F/u neuro recs, consider LP when stable
	+ Trend lactate
	+ Maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
	+ Continue to wean from ventilator
	+ Consider gallium scan if patient spikes another true fever
	+ F/u TFTs in 2 weeks
	+ Endocrine follow-up

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and further cardiac events may occur.
* Sepsis: The patient's fevers and metabolic acidosis may indicate sepsis, which could worsen if not addressed.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but further respiratory complications may arise if the ventilator weaning process is not managed properly.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen if not addressed, potentially leading to further cardiac and respiratory complications.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's neurological status is unstable, and further deterioration may occur if not managed properly.
* Bleeding complications: The patient's coagulopathy and pressor dependence may increase the risk of bleeding complications.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and addressing any potential complications promptly to prevent further deterioration.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, hypotension, and altered mental status. He was found unresponsive and pulseless, and underwent resuscitation. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His cardiac status is unstable, with a recent embolic stroke and cardiac arrest. He has also been diagnosed with bacteremia, likely related to line placement.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Lactic acid: 5.1 mmol/L (elevated)
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL (elevated)
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 37 mg/dL (elevated)
* Glucose: 297 mg/dL (elevated)
* White blood cell count (WBC): 28.8 K/uL (elevated)
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 10.1 g/dL (elevated)
* Platelet count (Plt): 147 K/uL (elevated)

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including:

* Vasopressors (phenylephrine, norepinephrine, and vasopressin)
* Antibiotics (vancomycin, piperacillin, and acyclovir)
* Insulin
* Anticoagulants (heparin)
* Pain medication (none listed)
* Sedatives (none listed)

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is already intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, but there is a risk of further respiratory compromise.
2. Cardiac instability: The patient has had a recent embolic stroke and cardiac arrest, and his cardiac status is unstable.
3. Bacteremia: The patient has been diagnosed with bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis and organ failure.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's lactic acid level is elevated, which can indicate poor perfusion and cardiac dysfunction.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level is elevated, which can increase the risk of complications such as infections and organ damage.
6. Hypothermia: The patient's temperature is cool, which can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
7. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status can increase the risk of complications such as falls and aspiration.

ICU care:

1. Nutrition: The patient is receiving tube feeds, and a nutrition consult is recommended.
2. Glycemic control: The patient's glucose level is elevated, and insulin therapy is recommended.
3. Lines: The patient has multiple lines, including an arterial line and a multi-lumen line.
4. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylactic antibiotics and anticoagulants.
5. VAP prevention: The patient is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and measures such as elevating the head of the bed and performing daily wake-up tests are recommended.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and hypotension. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a stable respiratory status.

The patient's neurological status is concerning, with evidence of multiple cerebral vascular accidents (CVAs) of unclear etiology. The patient is sedated and unable to provide a history, but periodically lifts his arms and opens his eyes to sternal rub.

The patient's cardiovascular status is critical, with a history of cardiac arrest and resuscitation. The patient remains on vasopressors to support blood pressure, and a cooling protocol was completed after the cardiac arrest.

The patient has a history of bacteremia attributed to line placement during the cardiac arrest, and is being treated with antimicrobials.

The patient's metabolic status is concerning, with metabolic acidosis and lactate levels of 5.1. This is likely due to cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, and increased afterload from the pressors and cooling.

The patient's infection status is unclear, with a diagnosis of FUO (fever of unknown origin) and an ongoing evaluation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is already intubated and mechanically ventilated, but there is a risk of further respiratory deterioration.
2. Neurological complications: The patient has had multiple CVAs and is at risk for further neurological damage.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has had a cardiac arrest and is at risk for further cardiac events.
4. Infection: The patient has bacteremia and is at risk for further infections.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely to continue unless the underlying cardiac dysfunction is addressed.
6. Fluid overload: The patient has received significant amounts of fluids and is at risk for fluid overload.
7. Renal failure: The patient's metabolic acidosis and lactate levels are concerning for potential renal failure.

The patient's care plan includes ongoing evaluation and management of the patient's respiratory, neurological, cardiovascular, and metabolic status. The patient will continue to receive antimicrobial therapy for bacteremia and will be monitored for signs of infection. The patient's glycemic control and nutrition will also be closely monitored.

   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated starting with neo
   - repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), admitted with fevers and hypotension, and subsequently developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, and pulseless. The patient was resuscitated and is currently undergoing extensive workup for fever of unknown origin (FUO).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on ventilator support with CPAP/PSV mode, and oxygenation is improving, with a RSBI of 31.
* Hemodynamic: The patient is still requiring pressor support, with vasopressin and norepinephrine infusions, and is able to be weaned off neosynephrine overnight.
* Neurological: The patient is unresponsive, with no assessment of movement, tone, or skin.
* Laboratory results:
	+ Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 28.8, Hct 31.1, Plt 147
	+ Blood chemistry: Glucose 126, Creatinine 1.9, Potassium 4.4, Calcium 7.1
	+ Other lab results: Troponin-T 0.06, ALT 29, AST 74, Alk Phos 138, Lactic Acid 3.0 mmol/L

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's RSBI is 31, which is concerning for respiratory failure. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status is necessary.
* Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, as evidenced by his need for pressor support and cardiac enzymes.
* Sepsis: The patient's fever of unknown origin and laboratory results suggesting hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia increase the risk of sepsis.
* Thrombotic complications: The patient's history of CAD and current anticoagulation therapy with subcutaneous heparin and pneumoboots increase the risk of thrombotic complications.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's current metabolic acidosis, likely due to cardiac dysfunction and poor forward flow, needs to be closely monitored and managed.
* Hypoalbuminemia: The patient's hypoalbuminemia, likely due to renal disease and poor PO, contributes to intravascular volume and pressure problems.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue pressor support and wean as tolerated
* Repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
* F/u blood and urine cultures
* Brain and C-spine MRI today
* Consider LP when stable
* Trend lactate
* Maintain pressors and wean as tolerated
* Continue to monitor fever curve
* F/u CRP
* Consider LP
* Continue ASA and statin
* Hold BB given hypotension
* Start insulin for hyperglycemia
* Nutrition consult for tube feeds
* Prophylaxis: subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
* Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line
* Communication: family
* Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
* Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated, now vasopressor
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - insulin sliding scale
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted with fevers and hypotension, and has undergone extensive workup for FUO with interval development of embolic hemorrhagic strokes. The patient was found unresponsive, asystolic, and pulseless, and underwent resuscitation.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on ventilator support with CPAP/PSV mode, and is oxygenating well with an FiO2 of 40%. The RSBI is improving.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is still requiring pressor support, with vasopressin and norepinephrine infusions. The blood pressure is 93/48 mmHg.
* Neurological: The patient is not assessed for peripheral vascular, skin, or neurologic function.
* Hematological: The patient has a WBC count of 28.8, Hct of 31.1, and Plt of 147.
* Renal: The patient has a creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 37 mg/dL.
* Metabolic: The patient has a metabolic acidosis with an anion gap of 17, and a lactate level of 3.0 mmol/L.
* Endocrine: The patient has hypoalbuminemia, and is being managed with IVF and repletion of electrolytes.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Sepsis: The patient has a high WBC count and is on antibiotics, which increases the risk of sepsis.
* Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, which may lead to further decompensation.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is on ventilator support, and may require further weaning or escalation of respiratory support.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine and BUN levels are elevated, which may indicate renal failure.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's anion gap is elevated, which may indicate a metabolic acidosis that requires further management.
* Endocrine dysfunction: The patient's hypoalbuminemia may indicate endocrine dysfunction, which requires further evaluation and management.

Based on this information, the patient's plan of care should include:

* Continued monitoring of vital signs and laboratory values
* Maintenance of pressor support and weaning as tolerated
* Continued respiratory support with CPAP/PSV mode
* Management of metabolic acidosis with IVF and repletion of electrolytes
* Endocrine evaluation and management
* Renal evaluation and management
* Sepsis evaluation and management
* Cardiac function evaluation and management
* Respiratory function evaluation and management.

 asytole as initial rhythm, may have experienced

   improving.  Would repeat.

   Monitor UO, BUN, creatinine.
   HYPONATREMIA -- total body water overloaded.  Would check serum/urine
   osmoles, urine electrolytes.  Would provide NS constant infusion,
   monitor serial Na.
   HYPERGLYCEMIA -- improved control.  Now off insulin infusion.  Maintain
   glucose <150.
   FUO
 unclear etiology.  Evaluation in progress.  Currently without

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted with a diagnosis of FUO (Fever of Unknown Origin) and underwent an extensive workup. He developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes, which led to cardiac arrest, and was successfully resuscitated. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.7째C (98.1째F)
* Heart rate: 86 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 112/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 inspirations per minute (ins/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 5 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 28.8 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit (Hct): 31.1%
* Platelet count (Plt): 147 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.9 mg/dL
* Total CO2 (TCO2): 17 mmHg
* Glucose: 126 mg/dL
* Other laboratory results include elevated lactate, ALT, AST, and LDH levels, as well as low albumin and calcium levels.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest with possible PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity)
* Sepsis
* Neurological impairment with evidence of multiple cerebral vasculitis
* Bacteremia attributed to line placement
* Metabolic acidosis
* Renal failure with non-oliguric acute kidney injury
* Hyponatremia
* Hyperglycemia

The patient's medications include:

* Vasopressors
* Fentanyl
* Famotidine (Pepcid)
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Acyclovir
* Vancomycin

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor SaO2
* Monitor for hypotension and hypovolemia
* Continue antimicrobials for bacteremia
* Monitor for metabolic acidosis and adjust treatment as needed
* Monitor for renal failure and adjust treatment as needed
* Monitor for hyperglycemia and adjust treatment as needed
* Continue ICU care with prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's code status is DNR (Do Not Resuscitate), and his disposition is ICU.

The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated, with stable vital signs and SaO2 of 99%. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and is receiving treatment for bacteremia, metabolic acidosis, renal failure, hypotension, and hyperglycemia.

The patient's neurological status is concerning, with evidence of multiple cerebrovascular accidents (CVAs) and unclear etiology. The patient is also at risk for sepsis, with a history of bacteremia and line placement. The patient's metabolic status is also concerning, with hypotension, hypocalcemia, and hyperglycemia.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with SaO2 of 99% and no signs of respiratory distress. The patient's cardiovascular status is also stable, with a heart rate of 86 beats per minute and blood pressure of 112/55 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and troponin-T, indicating possible sepsis and cardiac injury. The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 30.5 mg/dL.

The patient's medication regimen includes antibiotics, vasopressors, and heparin for prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient is also receiving stress ulcer prophylaxis and treatment for hyperglycemia.

The patient's ICU care plan includes continued mechanical ventilation, monitoring of SaO2, and management of bacteremia, metabolic acidosis, renal failure, hypotension, and hyperglycemia. The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR), and the patient is expected to remain in the ICU for further evaluation and treatment.

Potential medical complications that may arise in this patient include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's history of bacteremia and line placement puts them at risk for sepsis.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and cardiac injury may increase their risk for cardiac arrhythmias.

4. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and they may be at risk for further deterioration.
5. Neurological decline: The patient's neurological status is concerning, and they may be at risk for further decline if their underlying condition is not addressed.
6. Infection: The patient's bacteremia and line placement may increase their risk for infection.
7. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen if their underlying condition is not addressed.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen if their underlying condition is not addressed.

In conclusion, this patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of their underlying conditions to prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
 dc vancomycin as coag neg
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated, now only on levophed
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - f/u Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Thrombocytopoenia
 platelets today are 72, stepwise decline from 201
   on [**3-25**]^th. Most likely possibility is drug related (zosyn vs
   heparin vs vancomycin), could also be DIC (unlikely given stable HCT)
   or TTP. Unclear if this affects his prognosis
   - trend
   - DC heparin, vancomycin
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man admitted with fevers and hypotension, who developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes and was found unresponsive, asystolic, and pulseless. He was resuscitated and currently undergoes extensive workup for FUO (Fever of Unknown Origin). The patient is on pressor support, weaned off neosynephrine overnight, and is requiring ongoing management for thrombocytopenia, respiratory status, metabolic acidosis, and fevers of unknown origin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has decreased from 201 to 72, likely due to drug-related causes or DIC (Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation). This may affect his prognosis.
2. Respiratory Status: The patient is on ventilatory support and is improving, but requires continued weaning.
3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has a history of cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, and increased afterload due to pressors and cooling, which may contribute to his metabolic acidosis.
4. Fevers of Unknown Origin: The patient's fever curve has trended down, but he is still off antibiotics. Further monitoring and consideration of gallium scan or LP (Lumbar Puncture) may be necessary.
5. Hypoalbuminemia: The patient's renal disease and poor PO intake may contribute to his hypoalbuminemia, which may affect his intravascular volume and pressure.
6. Embolic Stroke: The patient is continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology, and consideration of Holter monitoring on discharge may be necessary.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient requires insulin sliding scale management to control his blood sugar levels.
8. Thrombotic Complications: The patient's history of CAD and chronic kidney disease may increase his risk of thrombotic complications.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of CAD and chronic kidney disease may also increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or obstruction.
10. Infection: The patient's fevers of unknown origin and history of respiratory alkalosis may increase his risk of infection.

Overall, the patient requires ongoing management and monitoring for these potential complications to ensure optimal care and improvement in his clinical condition.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, intubated and mechanically ventilated. The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, embolic hemorrhagic strokes, and is currently experiencing hypotension, neurological impairment, bacteremia, thrombocytopenia, metabolic acidosis, renal failure, hypornatremia, hyperglycemia, and unclear etiology of fever.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, aspiration, or worsening lung injury can lead to further respiratory decline.
2. Cardiac arrest: Recurrent cardiac arrest or arrhythmias can occur, particularly in the presence of underlying cardiac disease.
3. Neurological impairment: Stroke, cerebral edema, or sepsis can lead to worsening neurological deficits or even death.
4. Bacteremia: Sepsis, septic shock, or endocarditis can occur, particularly in the presence of central lines or other invasive devices.
5. Thrombocytopenia: Bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage, can occur.
6. Metabolic acidosis: Lactic acidosis, ketoacidosis, or other metabolic disturbances can worsen respiratory or cardiac function.
7. Renal failure: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, or uremic syndrome can develop, leading to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and anemia.
8. Hypornatremia: Hyponatremic seizures, cerebral edema, or other complications can occur, particularly in the presence of SIADH or other disorders of water balance.
9. Hyperglycemia: Diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome, or other complications can develop, particularly in the presence of diabetes or impaired glucose regulation.
10. Fever of unknown origin: Sepsis, endocarditis, or other infections can develop, particularly in the presence of underlying comorbidities or immunocompromise.

The patient's current treatment plan includes mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, antibiotics, and supportive care. Close monitoring and adjustment of treatment are necessary to address these potential complications and improve the patient's outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. He was found unresponsive and pulseless, and was resuscitated. He has a history of cardiac arrest, embolic hemorrhagic strokes, and sepsis.

The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a stable respiratory status. However, the main obstacle to extubation is his altered mental status. He has a history of multiple CVAs, and possible endocarditis is being considered. He also has bacteremia attributed to line placement during cardiac arrest.

The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is being monitored. He has metabolic acidosis, renal failure, and hypotension, which are being managed accordingly. He has hyperglycemia, which has improved with insulin infusion. He is receiving nutritional support and is being monitored for fever.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's history of bacteremia and sepsis, there is a risk of further septic episodes.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but there is a risk of further respiratory deterioration.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and sepsis, which increases the risk of cardiovascular instability.
4. Neurological complications: The patient has multiple CVAs and possible endocarditis, which increases the risk of further neurological complications.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is being monitored, but there is a risk of further decline in platelet count.
6. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, which increases the risk of further renal deterioration.
7. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is being managed, but there is a risk of further acidosis.
8. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is being managed, but there is a risk of further hypotension.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   MRI HEAD IMPRESSION:
   1. Multiple new foci of restricted diffusion scattered throughout both

   2. Cortical FLAIR hyperintensities in the biparietal cortices

   3. Stable central and cortical involutional changes as expected for the

   Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] was notified on [**2184-3-29**] at 10 a.m.
   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resuscitation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.  LP
   done.
   Mental status has improved and intermittently follows commands.
   - vancomycin, zosyn both discontinued per ID
   - wean pressors, now only on levophed
   - f/u bld, urine cx, LP cx
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   - CSF cultures, HSV, VZV, EBV, TB
   - TEE today to look for potential source of emboli
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 platelets today are 72, stepwise decline from 201
   on [**3-25**]^th. Most likely possibility is drug related (zosyn vs
   heparin vs vancomycin), could also be DIC (unlikely given stable HCT)
   or TTP. Unclear if this affects his prognosis
   - trend
   - DC heparin, vancomycin, famotidine
   - get DIC/TTP labs for now
   - guaiac stool
   - BMT for BM biopsy results
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   - plan to diurese as tolerates
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1 likely due to cardiac dysfunction, poor
   forward flow + increased afterload due to pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CSF results
   -- TEE
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   -question if need rheum consult
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - insulin sliding scale
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

**Medical History:**

* Patient is a 74-year-old man with a history of CAD, chronic kidney disease, stage III, and hyperlipidemia.
* He was admitted on [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension, and later developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes, unresponsiveness, and pulseless arrest.

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO (fever of unknown origin) with interval development of embolic hemorrhagic strokes.
* He is still requiring pressor support and has a moderate narrowing of the spinal canal at C3-4 secondary to a broad-based disc protrusion without evidence of cord signal abnormality.
* The patient has a stepwise decline in platelet count, which is likely due to drug-related thrombocytopenia (zosyn, heparin, or vancomycin) or TTP (thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura).
* He has a metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation and is being treated with pressors and cooling.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Infection:** The patient's fever of unknown origin and increased protein in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) suggest the possibility of an infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
2. **Thrombotic events:** The patient's thrombocytopenia and embolic hemorrhagic strokes increase the risk of further thrombotic events, including stroke, myocardial infarction, or pulmonary embolism.
3. **Respiratory failure:** The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he still requires ventilator support, which increases the risk of respiratory failure and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
4. **Kidney injury:** The patient's chronic kidney disease and potential nephrotoxicity from antibiotics and other medications increase the risk of kidney injury and acute kidney injury (AKI).
5. **Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules:** The patient's hypoalbuminemia and potential adrenal insufficiency increase the risk of hypothyroidism and adrenal nodules, which could lead to cardiovascular and metabolic complications.
6. **Hyperglycemia:** The patient's hyperglycemia increases the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome, and other metabolic complications.
7. **Hypotension:** The patient's hypotension increases the risk of organ dysfunction and failure, particularly in the kidneys, liver, and brain.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's fever curve, CSF results, and TEE (transesophageal echocardiogram) to determine the cause of his FUO and potential infections.
2. Manage the patient's thrombocytopenia with discontinuation of potential offending medications and consideration of platelet transfusions.
3. Wean the patient off pressors and cooling as tolerated.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider extubation if possible.
5. Manage the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin sliding scale and nutrition consult for tube feeds.
6. Monitor the patient's kidney function and consider nephrotoxicity from antibiotics and other medications.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's thyroid function and consider thyroid replacement therapy if necessary.
8. Consider a rheum consult to evaluate the patient's potential autoimmune disorders.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and consider a stress test or echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function.
10. Consider a nutrition consult to evaluate the patient's nutritional status and potential need for tube feeds.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 74-year-old man admitted with fevers and hypotension, who developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes and was found unresponsive, asystolic, and pulseless. He was resuscitated and is currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO (fever of unknown origin). The patient has a complex medical history, including CAD (coronary artery disease), chronic kidney disease, stage III, hyperlipidemia, and hypoalbuminemia.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: The patient remains hemodynamically unstable, requiring pressor support, and is still recovering from a prolonged PEA (pulsus paradoxus) arrest.
2. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has decreased stepwise from 201 to 72, which may be related to drug-induced thrombocytopenia, DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation), or TTP (thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura).
3. Respiratory status: The patient is oxygenating well and improving, with a plan to wean from the ventilator and diurese as tolerated.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation, likely due to cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, and increased afterload.
5. Fevers of unknown origin: The patient's fever curve has trended down, and the ID (infectious disease) team recommends a gallium scan only if he spikes another true fever.
6. Hypoalbuminemia: The patient's hypoalbuminemia is likely due to renal disease and poor PO (oral intake), contributing to intravascular volume and pressure problems.
7. Embolic stroke: The patient is continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology, with a plan to consider a holter on discharge and follow neuro recommendations.
8. Other conditions: The patient has hypoalbuminemia, hyperglycemia, and chronic kidney disease, stage III.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever of unknown origin and thrombocytopenia increase the risk of sepsis.
2. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and hypoalbuminemia may increase the risk of bleeding.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but weaning from the ventilator may be challenging.
4. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac dysfunction and hypotension may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest.
5. Infection: The patient's fevers of unknown origin and thrombocytopenia increase the risk of infection.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's hypoalbuminemia and thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and address any potential issues.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
 dc vancomycin as coag neg
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated, now only on levophed
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - f/u Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Thrombocytopoenia
 platelets today are 72, stepwise decline from 201
   on [**3-25**]^th. Most likely possibility is drug related (zosyn vs
   heparin vs vancomycin), could also be DIC (unlikely given stable HCT)
   or TTP. Unclear if this affects his prognosis
   - trend
   - DC heparin, vancomycin
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - insulin sliding scale
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
